I read a lot about Thomas Cook this weekend, the business had approx £3bn of net liabilities, masked by the goodwill and intangible assets on the balance sheet to provide a positive shareholders fund amount. In the 10 years to 2018 they had £2.7bn of separately disclosed items, paid tax of £566m, Interest of £1.3bn and facility set up fees of £150m. In the end they just did not pay suppliers and hence funded their working capital to the point there was nothing left. They spent £730m on intangible assets (mainly IT related) and spent £1.35bn on tangible assets. Dividends were £400m and net share issues were £211. Let us remember that their accounting was poor, mytravel were censured by the FCA for poor accounting, Arcandor (the former parent) went bust and closed Quelle and their stake in TCG was placed with institutional shareholders, and in looking further Jet2 Holidays just ate their lunch and they were left with a high cost legacy product, namely retail booked package holidays in structural decline. (would you believe 48% of holidays were still booked thru the retail network). Basically all the tech savvy folks booked elsewhere, and Thomas Cook was left with offline sales.

A leader: We view Burford as a market-leading specialist in the growing segment that is litigation finance. Burford is a high margin, high return business, but its margins are not out of line with the specialist lenders sub-sector. It is this combined subsector leading operating efficiency that drives its sector-leading Profit:Assets ratio. For
us, it is this ratio, as well as the ROE and COE, that drive valuation. Burford has delivered consistent growth and, while we believe its period-on-period growth profile is impossible to forecast and represents the greatest risk for investors, we expect it will continue to deliver a superior medium-term growth profile for investors.
● High returns with low leverage: While ROE is the prime driver of valuation, for us, how that ROE is constructed is critically important and we do not like ROE to be driven
by leverage. Burford achieved the third highest ROAE (36.4%), which was 24.4% ahead of the sub-sector average of 29.3%. However, Burford achieved its ROE, with a Cost:Income ratio of just 24.9% against an average of 43.5%. Its margin was 19.0% (the average was 25.9%) and it had by far the least leverage, its leverage ratio (Tangible equity/Assets) was 59.1% (the sector average was 19.2%)

BE11:48am

Top pick for long term investors … We remain committed to our Overweight thesis, despite expecting a relatively subdued quarter. We recently hosted management on the road in the US – see our Postcard from NYC here. To be positive on the shares, we think investors need to assume a combination of 1) the new outsider CEO Laxman Narasimhan brings a fresh start (New Outsider CEO…Fresh Start); 2) 2020 De-Risked: consensus already assumes a material margin reset in February 2020; 3) the problems that have beset the business particularly in Health can be resolved with reinvestment and/or a new strategy, 4) that the sum of the parts is supportive: by the end of 2020 we forecast RB to have ~£4bn of EBITDA with ~£2.5bn from Health and ~£1.4bn from HyHo; 5) RB 2.0 will bring improved operational performance to Health as well as HyHo and in the longer term it creates strategic optionality. Operational momentum likely to remain subdued for now. We forecast 2.6% LFL in Q3 (and 2.6% for Q4), with 2.9% from Health and 2.0% for Hygiene Home. We assume that underlying momentum in the Health business continues to be impacted by the trends seen in Q2 across Durex (competitor innovation), Dettol (input cost / competitor pressure) and Scholl (ongoing repositioning). As Hyho laps tougher comps, we expect it to perform at the lower end of the 2-3% category growth rate. We recently downgraded the HPC sector to In-Line from Attractive pointing to the resurgence of P&G (covered by Dara Mohsenian) and fading pricing: Pain & Gain...EU HPC Downgrade. We believe waning pricing will likely highlight the full pressure of P&G's resurgence on the top lines of the EU players.FY guidance is challenging… Remember Reckitt guided down FY top-line to 2-3% from 3-4% at the Q2. We now forecast 1.6% LFL for the FY (from 1.8%) which means that RB can make the 2% lower end guidance on a rounded basis. Whilst RB benefits from easier comps in Q3 (£70mn sales lost in Q318 at Mead, weak flu and Mucinex generic share loss), it also has tougher comps in areas such as OTC (6.5%). In addition, retailers tend to stock up for the forthcoming flu season on the basis of the prior flu season (which for 2018/9 was relatively soft).

Metro Bank (MTRO) featured in a number of press articles at the weekend. The Sunday Times noted that activist investors are circling the bank with a view to potentially taking a shareholding in the bank or purchasing debt in a private placement (read MREL issuance) at a higher coupon than the expected 7.5% coupon attached to last week’s aborted inaugural MREL-eligible debt issuance. The article notes that the activist funds (specifically mentions Elliott) are also considering opportunities to pluck off parts of the business, which we would read to mean asset sales. Some of the activists are understood to be demanding that, a condition of any investment in the business would be that the CEO, Craig Donaldson must depart. Separately, The Sunday Telegraph reported that the MTRO Chairman, Vernon Hill, is on the hunt for fresh investment in the bank – again, the article notes that Hill has been told by at least one potential backer that a new CEO will need to be hired to replace Craig Donaldson before any investment is made. This particular news report appears consistent with the piece in The Sunday Times.

In fact we see an investment in the debt with attached conversion rights as the more likely outcome if third party investment is indeed secured given the unique risks pertaining to MTRO at the current time [which make it hard to support the investment case for an outright purchase of equity]. While news of a potential solution is likely to prove share price-supportive in the near-term (look at what happened late on Friday, coming into the close…) we would caution shareholders that any third party investment could result in material dilution for existing shareholders – depending on how a transaction is structured of course. Secondly, the ability for MTRO to secure any such investment is obviously highly uncertain and may not materialise. Thirdly, uncertainties (capital requirements inflation, the outcome of the regulatory investigation, litigation risk, profitability question marks) continue to be significant. Any such significant investment would, in our view, see senior management departures (Chairman and CEO at least) and another recalibration of the strategy. We remind you again that we wrote extensively, in the early part of 2019, about how MTRO needs to recalibrate its strategy. We saw the announced refreshed strategy in February as just a tweak to existing plans rather than a sufficiently substantive overhaul ...

Therefore, it follows, at this juncture, that someone new needs to take charge. We think there is a prospect for an independent future for MTRO if the Board can act quickly to install a new strong CEO who has a realistic vision for the business.
